I want to take you, guys, on a quick tour around the issue of wireless - warrantless wiretapping.
So Verizon told House Democrats it provided information on more than 700 phone customers to the federal government.
They said the information was handed over in emergency cases.
Democrats on the House Energy - Commerce Committee are looking into the cooperation of the phone companies since September 11.
So Donna, is it too easy to get this information for the federal government?
Is there not enough protection for consumers?

Well, look, I think it is - first of all, let me just inform you that my company represent several of the telecom companies, including Verizon in their broadband expansion to minority, rural communities and others.
So I wanted to say that upfront.

I also believe that it's important that we protect individual rights and civil liberties, at the same time, give the intelligence communities the tools that they need without sacrificing those civil liberties.
I also believe that these telecom companies, you know, should be covered but as - in so far as going to the courts and making sure that this is all appropriate under the current FISA statute.
Now, I know the Democrats want to get to the bottom of it.
They're going to try to make sure that the telecommunication companies, you know, tell them as much information in terms of what they did in helping the Bush administration get access to information.
This is a very touchy issue.
And Congress should debate it thoroughly.
But the bottom line is no one should receive immunity if they violated the law.
That's a corporation or an individual.
You know, I'm going to put my lawyer head on.

I am in favor of FISA and I'm in favor of the government in very limited circumstances of being able to trace communications of terrorists or those who might be plotting incidents against the United States.
When I read this story yesterday, I was very concerned.

The Fourth Amendment provides against illegal searches and seizures unless there's an exigent circumstance, unless there's a very rapid need for this information to go to the hands of the government without first obtaining warrant.
I'm very interested to see why ordinary phone records were turned over.
And also, some of these records were dealing with people with child predator and other non-intelligence related issues.
So I do think that they should have it full airing.
Obviously, if it's related to a terrorist or it's relating to something that's going to harm this country, there is that exception under FISA.
But going without a warrant if it's not an exigent circumstance, I want to take a closer look at that.
Well, Ron and Donna, thanks so much.
Good to talk to you.
Thank you.
